info.text: The default category for questions shared in context '6.4 The Logarithmic Function'.

questiontext.text:
The logarithmic function Den logaritmiske funksjonen

Recall the operation of taking logarithms which reverses the operation of exponentiation. \[\qquad \text{If}\ a>0 \ \text{and}\ a\ne 1\ \ \text{then}\qquad x=a^y\qquad\text{implies}\qquad y=\log_ax\] In this quiz we consider the log function in more detail. We shall concentrate only on the functions \(\log x\) (i.e. to base \(10\)) and \(\ln x\) (i.e. to base \(e\)). The functions \(y=\log x\) and \(y=\ln x\) have similar characteristics. We can never choose \(x\) as a negative number since \(10^y\) and \(e^y\) are each always positive. The graphs of \(y=\log x\) and \(y=\ln x\) are shown in the figure below. Husk at logaritme operasjonen reverserer operasjonen til eksponentiering. \[\qquad \text{hvis}\ a>0 \ \text{og}\ a\ne 1\ \ \text{da impliserer}\qquad x=a^y\qquad\text{at}\qquad y=\ log_ax\] I denne quizen tar vi for oss logaritme funksjonen mer detaljert. Vi skal kun konsentrere oss om funksjonene \(\log x\) (dvs. av base \(10\)) og \(\ln x\) (dvs. av base \(e\)). Funksjonene \(y=\log x\) og \(y=\ln x\) har lignende egenskaper. Vi kan aldri velge \(x\) som et negativt tall siden \(10^y\) og \(e^y\) alltid er positive. Grafene til \(y=\log x\) og \(y=\ln x\) er vist i figuren nedenfor.

Logarithmic and exponential functions Logaritmiske og eksponentielle funksjoner

From the graphs we see that both functions are one-to-one so each has an inverse - the inverse function of \(\log_ax\) is \(a^x\). Let us do this for logs to base \(10\). Fra grafene ser vi at begge funksjonene er injektive, så hver har en invers - den inverse funksjonen til \(\log_ax\) er \(a^x\). La oss gjøre dette for log av base \(10\).

name.text: 6.4.2.1 Solving equations involving logarithms and exponentials

questiontext.text:
Solving equations involving logarithms and exponentials Løse ligninger som involverer logaritmer og eksponentialer

To solve equations which involve logarithms or exponentials we need to be aware of the basic laws which govern both of these mathematical concepts. We illustrate by considering some examples. For å løse ligninger som har logaritmer eller eksponentialer, må vi være klar over de grunnleggende lovene som styrer disse matematiske konseptene. Vi illustrerer dette ved å ta for oss noen eksempler.

Example Eksempel

Solve for the variable \(x\). Løs for variabelen \(x\).

  1. \(3=10^x\)
  2. \(10^{x/4}=\log_{10} 3\)
  3. \(\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\)

Solution Løsning

  1. Here we take logs (to base \(10\) because of the term \(10^x\)) of both sides to get \[ \log 3=\log 10^x=x\log 10=x \] where we have used the general property that \(\log_aA^k=k\log_aA\) and the specific property that \(\log 10=1\). Hence \(x=\log 3\) or, in numerical form, \(x=0.47712\) to \(5\) d.p. Her tar vi log (av base \(10\) på grunn av \(10^x\)) på begge sider for å få \[ \log 3=\log 10^x=x\log 10=x \] der vi har brukt den generelle egenskapen at \(\log_aA^k=k\log_aA\) og den spesifikke egenskapen at \(\log 10=1\). Dermed har vi \(x=\log 3\) eller, i numerisk form, \(x=0,47712\) til \(5\) d.p.
  2. The approach used in (a) is used here. Take logs of both sides: \[\log_{10}(10^{x/4})=\log_{10}(\log_{10}3)\] that is \[\dfrac{x}{4}\log_{10} 10=\log_{10} (\log_{10} 3)=\log_{10} (0.4771212)=-0.3213712.\] So, since \(\log_{10} 10=1\), we have \(x=4(-0.3213712)=-1.28549\) to \(5\) d.p. Metoden brukt i (a) brukes her. Vi tar log på begge sider: \[\log_{10}(10^{x/4})=\log_{10}(\log_{10}3)\] som gir \[\dfrac{x}{4} \log_{10} 10=\log_{10} (\log_{10} 3)=\log_{10} (0.4771212)=-0.3213712.\] Siden \(\log_{10} 10=1\), har vi \(x=4(-0,3213712)=-1,28549\) til \(5\) d.p.
  3. Here we simplify the expression before taking logs. \[\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\qquad\text{implies}\qquad 1=4(17-e^x)\] or \(4e^x=4(17)-1=67\) so \(e^x=16.75\). Now taking natural logs of both sides (because of the presence of the \(e^x\) term) we have: \[\ln (e^x)=\ln (16.75)=2.8183983.\] But \(\ln (e^x)=x\ln e=x\) and so the solution to \(\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\) is \(x=2.81840\) to \(5\) d.p. Her forenkler vi uttrykket før vi bruker log. \[\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\qquad\text{impliserer}\qquad 1=4(17-e^x)\] eller \(4e^x=4(17)-1 =67\) så \(e^x=16,75\). Når vi nå tar naturlige logaritme på begge sider (på grunn av \(e^x\)-begrepet), får vi: \[\ln (e^x)=\ln (16.75)=2.8183983.\] Men \(\ln (e^x)=x\ln e=x\) så løsningen til \(\dfrac{1 }{17-e^x}=4\) er \(x=2,81840\), til \(5\) d.p.

Example Eksempel

Find \(x\) if \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\). Bestem \(x\) hvis \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\).

Solution Løsning

We first simplify this expression by multiplying through by \(10^x\) (to eliminate the term \(10^{-x}\)): \[10^x(10^x)-10^x(5)+10^x(6(10^{-x}))=0,\] or \[(10^{x})^2-5(10^x)+6=0\qquad\text{since}\qquad 10^x(10^{-x})=10^0=1.\] Vi forenkler først dette uttrykket ved å multiplisere med \(10^x\) (for å eliminere \(10^{-x}\)): \[10^x(10^x)-10^x(5)+10^x(6(10^{-x}))=0,\] eller \[(10^{x})^2-5(10^x)+6=0\qquad\text{siden}\qquad 10^x(10^{-x})=10^0=1.\]

We realise that this expression is a quadratic equation. Let us put \(y=10^x\) to give \[y^2-5y+6=0.\] Vi innser at dette uttrykket er en andregradsligning. La oss sette \(y=10^x\) for å få \[y^2-5y+6=0.\]

Now, we can factorise to give \[(y-3)(y-2)=0 \qquad \text{so that}\qquad y=3\quad\text{or}\quad y=2.\] Nå kan vi faktorisere \[(y-3)(y-2)=0 \qquad \text{slik at}\qquad y=3\quad\text{eller}\quad y=2.\]

For each of these values of \(y\) we obtain a separate value for \(x\) since \(y=10^x\) For hver av disse verdiene av \(y\) får vi en egen verdi for \(x\) siden \(y=10^x\).


Case 1 If \(y=3\) then \(3=10^x\) implying \(x=\log_{10} 3=0.4771212\). Tilfelle 1 Hvis \(y=3\) så er \(3=10^x\) som impliserer at \(x=\log_{10} 3=0,4771212\).


Case 2 If \(y=2\) then \(2=10^x\) implying \(x=\log_{10} 2=0.3010300\). Tilfelle 2 Hvis \(y=2\) så er \(2=10^x\) som impliserer at \(x=\log_{10} 2=0,3010300\).


We conclude that the equation \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\) has two possible solutions for \(x\): either \(x=\log_{10} 3\) or \(x=\log_{10} 2\). Vi konkluderer med at ligningen \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\) har to mulige løsninger for \(x\): enten \(x=\log_{10} 3\) eller \(x=\log_{10} 2\).

Arrhenius' law Arrhenius lov

Introduction Introduksjon

Chemical reactions are very sensitive to temperature; normally, the rate of reaction increases as temperature increases. For example, the corrosion of iron and the spoiling of food are more rapid at higher temperatures. Chemically, the probability of collision between two molecules increases with temperature, and an increased collision rate results in higher kinetic energy, thus increasing the proportion of molecules that have the activation energy for the reaction, i.e. the minimum energy required for a reaction to occur. Based upon his observations, the Swedish chemist, Svante Arrhenius, proposed that the rate of a chemical reaction increases exponentially with temperature. This relationship, now known as Arrhenius' law, is written as Kjemiske reaksjoner er svært følsomme for temperatur; vanligvis øker reaksjonshastigheten når temperaturen øker. For eksempel er korrosjon av jern og nedbryting av mat raskere ved høyere temperaturer. Kjemisk øker sannsynligheten for kollisjon mellom to molekyler med temperaturen, og en økt kollisjonshastighet resulterer derfor i høyere kinetisk energi som øker antall molekyler som har tilstrekkelig aktiveringsenergi for reaksjonen, dvs. minimumsenergien nødvendig for at en reaksjon skal oppstå. Basert på observasjoner foreslo den svenske kjemikeren Svante Arrhenius at hastigheten på en kjemisk reaksjon øker eksponentielt med temperaturen. Dette forhold, nå kjent som Arrhenius lov, er skrevet som

\[k = k_0 \, \exp \left( \frac{-E_a}{R\,T} \right) \qquad (1)\]

where \(k\) is the reaction rate constant, \(k_0\) is the frequency factor, \(E_a\)is the activation energy, \(R\) is the universal gas constant and \(T\) is the absolute temperature. Thus, the reaction rate constant, \(k\), depends on the quantities \(k_0\) and \(E_a\), which characterise a given reaction, and are generally assumed to be temperature independent. hvor \(k\) er reaksjonshastighetskonstanten, \(k_0\) er frekvensfaktoren, \(E_a\) er aktiveringsenergien, \(R\) er den universelle gass konstanten og \(T\) er den absolutte temperaturen. Altså avhenger reaksjonshastighetskonstant, \(k\), av mengdene \(k_0\) og \(E_a\), som karakteriserer en gitt reaksjon, og er antatt temperaturuavhengige.

Problem in words Problemet i ord

In a laboratory, ethyl acetate is reacted with sodium hydroxide to investigate the reaction kinetics. Calculate the frequency factor and activation energy of the reaction from Arrhenius' Law, using the experimental measurements of temperature and reaction rate constant in the table: I et laboratorium reagerer etylacetat med natrium hydroksyd for å undersøke reaksjonskinetikken. Beregn frekvensfaktoren og aktiveringsenergien til reaksjonen med Arrhenius' lov, ved bruk av eksperimentelle målinger av temperatur og reaksjonshastighetskonstant, gitt i tabellen:

\(T\) 310 350
\(k\) 7.757192 110.9601

Mathematical statement of problem Matematisk problemformulering

Given that \(k = 7.757192 s^{-1}\) at \(T = 310 K\) and \(k = 110.9601 s^{-1}\) at \(T = 350 K\), use Equation (1) to produce two linear equations in \(E_a\) and \(k_0\). Solve these to find \(E_a\) and \(k_0\). (Assume that the gas constant \(R = 8.314 J K^{-1} \text{mol}^{-1}.\)) Gitt at \(k = 7,757192 s^{-1}\) ved \(T = 310 K\) og \(k = 110,9601 s^{-1}\) ved \(T = 350 K\), bruk ligning (1) for å produsere to lineære ligninger med \(E_a\) og \(k_0\). Løs disse for å finne \(E_a\) og \(k_0\). (Anta at gasskonstanten \(R = 8,314 J K^{-1} \text{mol}^{-1}.\))

Mathematical analysis Matematisk analyse

Taking the natural logarithm of both sides of (1) Ta den naturlige logaritmen til begge sider av (1)

\[\ln k = \ln \left\{k_0 \, \exp\left(\frac{-E_a}{R\,T}\right)\right\}= \ln k_0 - \frac{E_a}{R\,T}.\] Now inserting the experimental data gives the two linear equations in \(E_a\) and \(k_0\) \[\ln k_1 = \ln k_0 - {\frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}} \qquad (2)\] \[\ln k_2 = \ln k_0 - \frac{E_a}{R\,T_2} \qquad (3)\] where \(k_1 = 7.757192\), \(T_1 = 310\) and \(k_2 = 110.9601\), \(T_2 = 350\). \[\ln k = \ln \left\{k_0 \, \exp\left(\frac{-E_a}{R\,T}\right)\right\}= \ln k_0 - \frac{E_a}{R\,T}.\] Innsetting av den eksperimentelle dataen gir de to lineære ligningene med \(E_a\) og \(k_0\) \[\ln k_1 = \ln k_0 - {\frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}} \qquad (2)\] \[\ln k_2 = \ln k_0 - \frac{E_a}{R\,T_2} \qquad (3)\] der \(k_1 = 7.757192\), \(T_1 = 310\) og \(k_2 = 110.9601\), \(T_2 = 350\).

Firstly, to find \(E_a\), subtract Equation (2) from Equation (3) \[\ln k_2-\ln k_1= \dfrac{E_a}{R\,T_1}-\dfrac{E_a}{R\,T_2}= \dfrac{E_a}{R} \left( \dfrac{1}{T_1} - \dfrac{1}{T_2} \right)\] so that \[E_a = \frac{R\,(\ln k_2-\ln k_1)}{\left(\frac{1}{T_1}-\frac{1}{T_2}\right)}\] and substituting the values gives \[E_a= 60 000 \mbox{ J mol}^{-1} = 60 \mbox{ kJ mol}^{-1}\] Secondly, to find \(k_0\), from (2) \[\ln k_0 = \ln k_1 + \frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\] which implies \[k_0 = \exp \left( \ln k_1 + \frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\right)= k_1 \, \exp \left(\frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\right)\] and substituting the values gives \[k_0= 1.0 \times 10^{11} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\] Først, for å finne \(E_a\), trekk ligning (2) fra ligning (3) \[\ln k_2-\ln k_1= \dfrac{E_a}{R\,T_1}-\dfrac{E_a}{R\,T_2}= \dfrac{E_a}{R} \left( \dfrac{1}{T_1} - \dfrac{1}{T_2} \right)\] slik at \[E_a = \frac{R\,(\ln k_2-\ln k_1)}{\left(\frac{1}{T_1}-\frac{1}{T_2}\right)}\] Å sette inn verdiene gir \[E_a= 60 000 \mbox{ J mol}^{-1} = 60 \mbox{ kJ mol}^{-1}\] For det andre, for å finne \(k_0\), fra (2) \[\ln k_0 = \ln k_1 + \frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\] som impliserer \[k_0 = \exp \left( \ln k_1 + \frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\right)= k_1 \, \exp \left(\frac{E_a}{R\,T_1}\right)\] og substituere verdiene gir \[k_0= 1.0 \times 10^{11} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\]

Solving equations involving hyperbolic functions Løse ligninger som involverer hyperbolske funksjoner

As a final example we consider equations involving the hyperbolic functions. Som et siste eksempel vurderer vi ligninger som involverer hyperbolske funksjoner.

Example Eksempel

Solve the equations : Løs ligningene:

  1. \(\sinh 3x=0\)
  2. \(\cosh 3x=2\)
  3. \(2\cosh^2x=3\cosh 2x-3\)

Solution Løsning

  1. From its graph we know that \(\sinh x=0\) only when \(x=0\), so we need \(3x=0\) which implies \(x=0\). Fra grafen vet vi at \(\sinh x=0\) bare når \(x=0\), så \(3x=0\), som innebærer \(x=0\).
  2. \[\cosh 3x=2 \qquad \text{ implies } \qquad \dfrac{e^{3x}+e^{-3x}}{2}=2 \qquad \text{ or } \qquad e^{3x}+e^{-3x}-4=0.\] Now multiply through by \(e^{3x}\) (to eliminate the term \(e^{-3x}\)) to give \[e^{3x}e^{3x}+e^{3x}e^{-3x}-4e^{3x}=0 \qquad \text{ or } \qquad (e^{3x})^2-4e^{3x}+1=0.\] This is a quadratic equation in the variable \(e^{3x}\) so substituting \(y=e^{3x}\) gives \[y^2-4y+1=0\qquad \text{implying}\qquad y=2\pm\sqrt{3}\quad \text{so}\quad y=3.7321\quad\text{or}\quad 0.26795\] \[ \qquad e^{3x}=3.7321\qquad \text{implies}\qquad x=\dfrac{1}{3}\ln 3.7321=0.439\quad\text{to 3 d.p.}\] \[ \qquad e^{3x}=0.26795\qquad \text{implies}\qquad x=\dfrac{1}{3}\ln 0.26795=-0.439\quad\text{to 3 d.p.}\] \[\cosh 3x=2 \qquad \text{ impliserer } \qquad \dfrac{e^{3x}+e^{-3x}}{2}=2 \qquad \text{ eller } \qquad e^{3x}+e^{-3x}-4=0.\] Multipliser med \(e^{3x}\) på begge sider (for å eliminere \(e^{-3x}\)) og få \[e^{3x}e^{3x}+e^{3x}e^{-3x}-4e^{3x}=0 \qquad \text{ eller } \qquad (e^{3x})^2-4e^{3x}+1=0.\] Dette er en andregradsligning med variabelen \(e^{3x}\) så \(y=e^{3x}\) gir \[y^2-4y+1=0\qquad \text{som impliserer}\qquad y=2\pm\sqrt{3}\quad \text{så}\quad y=3.7321\quad\text{eller}\quad 0.26795\] \[ \qquad e^{3x}=3.7321\qquad \text{impliserer}\qquad x=\dfrac{1}{3}\ln 3.7321=0.439\quad\text{med 3 d.p.}\] \[ \qquad e^{3x}=0.26795\qquad \text{impliserer}\qquad x=\dfrac{1}{3}\ln 0.26795=-0.439\quad\text{med 3 d.p.}\]
  3. We first simplify this expression by using the identity: \(\cosh 2x=2\cosh^2-1\). Thus the original equation \(2\cosh^2x=3\cosh 2x-3\) becomes \(\cosh 2x+1=3\cosh 2x-3\) or, when written in terms of exponentials: \[\dfrac{e^{2x}+e^{-2x}}{2}=3\left(\dfrac{e^{2x}+e^{-2x}}{2}\right)-4.\] Multiplying through by \(2e^{2x}\) gives \(e^{4x}+1=3(e^{4x}+1)-8e^{2x}\) or, after simplifying: \[e^{4x}-4e^{2x}+1=0.\] Writing \(y=e^{2x}\) we easily obtain \(y^2-4y+1=0\) with solution (using the quadratic formula): \[y=\dfrac{4\pm \sqrt{16-4}}{2}=2\pm\sqrt{3}\] If \(y=2+\sqrt{3}\) then \(2+\sqrt{3}=e^{2x}\) implying \(x=0.65848\) to \(5\) d.p. If \(y=2-\sqrt{3}\) then \(2-\sqrt{3}=e^{2x}\) implying \(x=-0.65848\) to \(5\) d.p. Vi forenkler først uttrykket ved å bruke identiteten: \(\cosh 2x=2\cosh^2-1\). Dermed blir originalligningen \(2\cosh^2x=3\cosh 2x-3\) til \(\cosh 2x+1=3\cosh 2x-3\) eller, på eksponensialform: \[\dfrac{e^{2x}+e^{-2x}}{2}=3\left(\dfrac{e^{2x}+e^{-2x}}{2}\right)-4.\] Multiplisere med \(2e^{2x}\) gir \(e^{4x}+1=3(e^{4x}+1)-8e^{2x}\) eller, etter forenkling: \[e^{4x}-4e^{2x}+1=0.\] Med \(y=e^{2x}\) får vi enkelt \(y^2-4y+1=0\) med løsningen (funnet med abc-formelen): \[y=\dfrac{4\pm \sqrt{16-4}}{2}=2\pm\sqrt{3}\] Hvis \(y=2+\sqrt{3}\) er \(2+\sqrt{3}=e^{2x}\) som impliserer \(x=0.65848\) med \(5\) d.p. Hvis \(y=2-\sqrt{3}\) er \(2-\sqrt{3}=e^{2x}\) som impliserer \(x=-0.65848\) med \(5\) d.p.

Example Eksempel

Solve for \(x\) if \(3\ln x+4\log_{10} x=1\). Finn \(x\) hvis \(3\ln x+4\log_{10} x=1\).

Solution Løsning

This has logs to two different bases. So we must first express each logarithm in terms of logs to the same base, \(e\) say Recall Vi har logaritmer med to forskjellige baser. Først må vi uttrykke hver logaritme med samme base, \(e\). Husk at

\[\log_{10} x=\dfrac{\ln x}{\ln 10}.\] Så \(3\ln x+4\log x=1\) blir \[ 3\ln x+4\dfrac{\ln x}{\ln 10}=1\qquad\text{eller}\qquad \left(3+\dfrac{4}{\ln 10}\right)\ln x=1\] Dette leder til \(\ln x=\dfrac{\ln 10}{3\ln 10 +4}=\dfrac{2.302585}{10.907755}=0.211096\) slik at \[ x=e^{0.211096}=1.2350311.\]

Exercise Øving

Solve the equation \({@exp@}={@n1@}\). To write your answer as a natural logarithm please write \(\log(n)\). Løs ligningen \({@exp@}={@n1@}\). For å skrive svaret ditt som en naturlig logaritme, skriv \(\log(n)\).

\( x= \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: We have that \({@exp@}={@n1@}\) implies \(e^x = \sqrt{@n1@}\) where we take the positive square root as exponential functions are always positive. Taking logarithms of both sides gives \[x = \ln(\sqrt{@n1@}) = \frac{\ln({@n1@})}{2}.\] Vi har at \({@exp@}={@n1@}\) som impliserer \(e^x = \sqrt{@n1@}\) hvor vi tar den positive kvadratroten, siden eksponentialfunksjoner alltid er positive . Å ta logaritmen på begge sider gir \[x = \ln(\sqrt{@n1@}) = \frac{\ln({@n1@})}{2}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: The logarithm of a negative number is not defined in the \( \mathbb{R}.\)

falsefeedback.text: The value of \((e^x)^2\) for your input is \({@ev(e^(2*ans1),simp)@}\) which is not equal to {@n1@}.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Solve the equation \({@exp@}={@n1@}e^x\) Løs ligningen \({@exp@}={@n1@}e^x\)

\( x= \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: We have that \[{@exp@}={@n1@}e^x \text{ implies } \frac{{@exp@}}{e^x} = {@n1@}.\] Hence \[\frac{{@exp@}}{e^x} = e^{2x-x} = e^x = {@n1@}\] and so, by taking logarithms of both sides \[x = \ln({@n1@}).\] Vi har at \[{@exp@}={@n1@}e^x \text{ impliserer } \frac{{@exp@}}{e^x} = {@n1@}.\] Dermed får vi \[\frac{{@exp@}}{e^x} = e^{2x-x} = e^x = {@n1@}\] og så, ved å ta logaritmen fra begge sider finner vi at \[x = \ln({@n1@}).\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text: Your solution implies that \({@ev(e^(2*ans1),simp)@}={@ev(n1*e^(ans1),simp)@}\) which is incorrect.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Solve the following equation for \(x\). Løs følgende ligning for \(x\).

\[\displaystyle{{@exp2@}=0}\]

\(x=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

\(x=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

generalfeedback.text:
First write this equation as a quadratic in the variable \(y=e^x\) remembering that \(e^{2x}\equiv (e^x)^2\): \[{@exp2@} \, \text{ becomes } \, {@expiny@}=0.\] Now solve the quadratic for \(y\): \[{@expiny@}=0 \, \text{ implies } \, (y-{@aa@})(y-{@bb@})=0.\] Therefore \(y={@aa@}\) or \(y={@bb@}.\) Skriv først denne ligningen som en andregradsligning med variabelen \(y=e^x\) og husk at \(e^{2x}\equiv (e^x)^2\): \[{@exp2@} \, \text{ blir } \, {@expiny@}=0.\] Løs nå ligningen for \(y\): \[{@expiny@}=0 \, \text{ impliserer } \, (y-{@aa@})(y-{@bb@})=0.\] Derfor er \(y={@aa@}\) eller \(y={@bb@}.\)

Finally, for each of your values of \(y\), find \(x\): Til slutt, for hver av verdiene for \(y\), finn \(x\):

Case 1 If \(y={@aa@}\) then \({@aa@}=e^x\) implies \(x=\ln {@aa@}\); Tilfelle 1 Hvis \(y={@aa@}\) så impliserer \({@aa@}=e^x\) at \(x=\ln {@aa@}\);

Case 2 If \(y={@bb@}\) then \({@bb@}=e^x\) implies \(x=\ln {@bb@}.\) Tilfelle 2 Hvis \(y={@bb@}\) så impliserer \({@bb@}=e^x\) at \(x=\ln {@bb@}.\)

questionvariables.text: aa : 2+rand(3) bb : 5+rand(5) ta1 : log(aa) ta2 : log(bb) exp2 : expand((e^x-aa)*(e^x-bb)) expiny : expand((y-aa)*(y-bb))

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

The temperature \(T\), in degrees C, of a chemical reaction is given by the formula \[\displaystyle{T={@aa@}e^{{@b2@}t}}\] where \(t\geq 0\) is the time, in seconds. Temperaturen \(T\), i grader C, in en kjemisk reaksjon er gitt av formelen \[\displaystyle{T={@aa@}e^{{@b2@}t}}\] der \(t\geq 0\) er tiden, i sekunder.

Calculate the time taken for the temperature to reach \({@cc@}^\circ \text{C}.\) Please give your answer to 3 significant figures. Beregn tiden det tar før temperaturen når \({@cc@}^\circ \text{C}.\) Vennligst gi svaret med 3 gjeldenede gjeldende sifre.

\( t = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] \( \textrm{s}\)

generalfeedback.text: We solve \[{@cc@}={@aa@}e^{{@b1@}t}.\] Rearranging gives \[e^{{@b1@}t} = \frac{{@cc@}}{{@aa@}}\] and taking logarithms \[t = \frac{1}{{@b1@}} \ln\left(\frac{{@cc@}}{{@aa@}}\right) \approx {@fl@} .\] So the time is {@dispsf(ta,3)@} seconds (to 3 s.f.). Vi løser \[{@cc@}={@aa@}e^{{@b1@}t}.\] Omorganisering gir \[e^{{@b1@}t} = \frac{{@cc@}}{{@aa@}}\] Når vi tar logaritmen får vi at \[t = \frac{1}{{@b1@}} \ln\left(\frac{{@cc@}}{{@aa@}}\right) \ca. {@fl@} .\] Så tiden er {@dispsf(ta,3)@} sekunder (til 3 s.f.).

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

The reaction Reaksjonen

2NO\(_2\)(g) \(\longrightarrow\) 2NO(g) + O\(_2\)(g)

has a reaction rate constant of \(1.0 \times 10 ^{-10}\) \(\text{s}^{-1}\) at \(300 \text{K}\) and activation energy of \(111 \text{kJ mol}^{-1} = 111 000\text{ J mol}^{-1}\). Use Arrhenius' law to find the reaction rate constant at a temperature of {@Tt@}\(\text{K}\). Please give your answer to \(4\) s.f. har en reaksjonshastighetskonstant på \(1,0 \times 10 ^{-10}\) \(\text{s}^{-1}\) ved \(300 \text{K}\) og aktiveringsenergi på \(111 \text{kJ mol}^{-1} = 111 000\text{ J mol}^{-1}\). Bruk Arrhenius lov for å finne reaksjonshastighetskonstanten ved en temperatur på {@Tt@}\(\text{K}\). Vennligst gi ditt svar til \(4\) gjeldende sifre

\( k = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Rearranging Arrhenius' equation gives \[k_0 = k \, \exp\left(\frac{E_a}{R\,T}\right).\] Substituting the values gives \[k_0= 2.126 \times 10^{9} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\] Now we use this value of \(k_0\) with \(E_a\) in Arrhenius' equation (1) to find \(k\) at \(T\) = {@Tt@} K \[k= k_0 \, \exp \left( \frac{-E_a}{R\,T} \right)= {@tar@} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\] Omorganisering av Arrhenius' ligning gir \[k_0 = k \, \exp\left(\frac{E_a}{R\,T}\right).\] Å subsituere verdiene gir \[k_0= 2.126 \times 10^{9} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\] Nå bruker vi denne verdien av \(k_0\) med \(E_a\) i Arrhenius' ligning (1) til å finne \(k\) på \(T\) = {@Tt@} K \[k= k_0 \, \exp \left( \frac{-E_a}{R\,T} \right)= {@tar@} \mbox{ s}^{-1}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
v Øving

For a chemical reaction with frequency factor \(k_0 = 0.5 \, \text{s}^{-1}\) and ratio \(E_a/R={@Tt@} \, \text{K}\), use Arrhenius' law to find the temperature at which the reaction rate constant would be equal to \(0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}\). Please give your answer to \(3\) s.f. For en kjemisk reaksjon med frekvensfaktor \(k_0 = 0,5 \, \text{s}^{-1}\) og forhold \(E_a/R={@Tt@} \, \text{K}\), bruk Arrhenius lov for å finne temperaturen der reaksjonshastighetskonstanten vil være lik \(0,1 \, \text{s}^{-1}\). Vennligst gi ditt svar til \(3\) gjeldende siffer

\( T = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] \( \text{K}\)

generalfeedback.text: Rearranging Equation (1) \[\frac{k}{k_0} = \exp \left( \frac{-E_a}{R\,T} \right).\] Taking the natural logarithm of both sides \[\ln \left( \frac{k}{k_0} \right) = \frac{-E_a}{R\,T}\] so that \[T = \frac{-E_a}{R\,\ln \left( k/k_0 \right)}= \frac{E_a}{R\,\ln \left( k_0/k \right)}.\] Substituting the values gives \(T={@ta@} \mbox{ K}.\) Omorganisering av ligning (1) gir \[\frac{k}{k_0} = \exp \left( \frac{-E_a}{R\,T} \right).\] Så tar den naturlige logaritmen til begge sider \[\ln \left( \frac{k}{k_0} \right) = \frac{-E_a}{R\,T}\] slik at \[T = \frac{-E_a}{R\,\ln \left( k/k_0 \right)}= \frac{E_a}{R\,\ln \left( k_0/k \right)}.\] Substituere verdiene gir \(T={@ta@} \mbox{ K}.\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Find the solution for \(x\) if \(\tanh x=\displaystyle{@bb@}\). Give a precise answer. Finn løsningen for \(x\) hvis \(\tanh x=\displaystyle{@bb@}\). Gi et presist svar.

\( x = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: First re-write \(\tanh x\) in terms of exponentials: \[\tanh x=\dfrac{e^x-e^{-x}}{e^x+e^{-x}}=\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}\] Now substitute into \(\tanh x={@bb@}\): \(\tanh x={@bb@}\) implies \[\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}={@bb@}\] so, on simplifying, \[\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}={@bb@} \text{ implies } (e^{2x}-1)=\dfrac{1}{{@aa@}}(e^{2x}+1)\] so \(\dfrac{({@aa@}-1)e^{2x}}{{@aa@}}=\dfrac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}}\) so, finally, \(e^{2x}=\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1}\). Now complete your solution by finding \(x\): \[e^{2x}=\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1} \text{ so } x= \dfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1}\right) = \dfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(\frac{{@aa+1@}}{{@aa-1@}}\right).\] Alternatively, many calculators can directly calculate the inverse function \(\tanh^{-1}\). If you have such a calculator then you can use the fact that \[\tanh x={@bb@} \qquad \text{implies} \qquad x=\tanh^{-1}{@bb@}\] to obtain \(x\) directly. Skriv først \(\tanh x\) om til: \[\tanh x=\dfrac{e^x-e^{-x}}{e^x+e^{-x}}=\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}\] Sett nå inn \(\tanh x={@bb@}\): \(\tanh x={@bb@}\) impliserer \[\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}={@bb@}\] så, ved forenkling, \[\dfrac{e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}={@bb@} \text{ impliserer } (e^{2x}-1)=\dfrac{1}{{@aa@}}(e^{2x}+1)\] så \(\dfrac{({@aa@}-1)e^{2x}}{{@aa@}}=\dfrac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}}\) så, endelig, \(e^{2x}=\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1}\). Fullfør løsningen ved å finne \(x\): \[e^{2x}=\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1} \text{ så } x= \dfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(\frac{{@aa@}+1}{{@aa@}-1}\right) = \dfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(\frac{{@aa+1@}}{{@aa-1@}}\right).\] Alternativt kan mange kalkulatorer direkte beregne den inverse funksjonen \(\ tanh^{-1} \). Hvis du har en slik kalkulator, kan du bruke det faktumet at \[\tanh x={@bb@} \qquad \text{impliserer} \qquad x=\tanh^{-1}{@bb@}\] for å finne \(x\) direkte.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: You need to give a precise answer, you should expect an expression involving logs.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Solve for the variable \(x\). To write your answer as a logarithm to base \(n\), please write Løs for variabelen \(x\). For å skrive svaret ditt som en logaritme til basen \(n\), vennligst skriv log_n(m).

  1. \({@a1*%pi@} =10^x\)

    [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(10^{-x/{@b1@}}={@b2@}\)

    [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(\dfrac{1}{{@c1@}-\pi^x}={@c2@}\). Please do not use logarithms to base \(\pi\) in your answer. Vennligst ikke bruk logaritmer med basen \(\pi\) i svaret.

    [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. \({@a1*%pi@} =10^x\)

    We take logs of base \(10\) on both sides: Vi tar logaritmen med base 10 på begge sider:

    \(\log(10^x) =\log{@a1@}\pi \Rightarrow\)

    \(x \log(10) =\log{@a1@}\pi \Rightarrow\)

    \(x =\log{@a1@}\pi.\)

  2. \(10^{-x/{@b1@}}={@b2@}\)

    We take logs of base \(10\) on both sides: Vi tar logaritmen med base 10 på begge sider:

    \(\log(10^{-x/{@b1@}}) = \log{@b2@} \Rightarrow\)

    \( -\dfrac{x}{@b1@} \log10 = \log{@b2@} \Rightarrow\)

    \(x=-{@b1@}\log {@b2@}.\)

  3. \(\dfrac{1}{{@c1@}-\pi^x}={@c2@}\)

    Here we simplify the expression before taking logs of base \(10\) on both sides: Her forenkler vi uttrykket før vi tar logaritmen med base 10 på begge sider:

    \({@c2@}({@c1@}-\pi^x)=1 \Rightarrow\)

    \(\pi^x={@(c1*c2-1)/c2@} \Rightarrow\)

    \(\log(\pi^x)= \log{@(c1*c2-1)/c2@} \Rightarrow\)

    \(x \log(\pi)= \log{@(c1*c2-1)/c2@} \Rightarrow\)

    \(x={@tac@}.\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Solve the equations Løs ligningene

  1. \(e^{2x}={@d1@}e^x\)

    [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]

  2. \({@exp2@}=0\)

    [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] [[feedback:prt5]]

  3. \(\cosh x={@f1@}\)

    \(x=\) [[input:ans6]][[validation:ans6]]

    \(x=\)[[input:ans7]][[validation:ans7]][[feedback:prt6]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. \(e^{2x}={@d1@}e^x\)

    Take logs of base \(e\) on both sides: Ta logaritmen av basen \(e\) på begge sider:

    \(\ln(e^{2x}) = \ln({@d1@}e^x) \Rightarrow\)

    \(2x=\ln {@d1@}+x \Rightarrow x=\ln {@d1@}.\)

  2. \({@exp2@}=0\)

    Let \(y=e^x,\) then the equation becomes \({@expiny@}=0.\) La \(y=e^x,\) så ligningen blir \({@expiny@}=0.\)

    By solving the quadratic we find: \(y={@e1@}\) or \(y={@e2@}\) (we cannot take the negative root since exponentials can never be negative). Ved å løse andregradsligningen finner vi: \(y={@e1@}\) eller \(y={@e2@}\) (vi kan ikke ta den negative roten siden eksponentialer aldri kan være negative).

    Thus \(e^x= {@e1@} \Rightarrow x=\ln ({@e1@}).\) Da har vi \(e^x= {@e1@} \Rightarrow x=\ln ({@e1@}).\)

  3. \(e^x+e^{-x}={@f12@}\)can be written as \({@exp3@}=0.\) \(e^x+e^{-x}={@f12@}\) kan skrives som \({@exp3@}=0.\)

    Let \(y=e^x,\) then the equation becomes \({@y^2-2*f1*y+1@} =0. \) La \(y=e^x,\) så ligningen blir \({@y^2-2*f1*y+1@} =0. \)

    By solving the quadratic we find: Ved å løse andregradsligningen finner vi: \(y = e^x = \dfrac{{@f12@} \pm \sqrt{({@f12@})^2-4}}{2} = {@f1@} \pm \sqrt{{@f1@}^2-1}.\)

    We accept both roots since both are positive. Vi aksepterer begge røttene siden begge er positive.

    Finally we have \(x={@tf1@}\) or \(x={@tf2@}.\) Endelig har vi \(x={@tf1@}\) eller \(x={@tf2@}.\)

questionvariables.text:
d1 : 17 + rand(5) tad : log(d1)
e1: 2+ rand(5) e2: -3 + rand(3) tae: log(e1) exp2 : expand((e^x-e1)*(e^x-e2)) expiny : expand((y-e1)*(y-e2))
f1 : 3 + rand(5) f12:2*f1 exp3 : e^(2*x)-2*f1*e^(x)+1 tf1 : log(f1+sqrt(f1^2-1)) tf2 : log(f1-sqrt(f1^2-1))

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
